hints_html:
This is actually kind of a first order differential equation disguised as a second order differential equation. Try an integrating factor.

Multiply both sides of the equation by

\(e^{-2x}\)

where the -2 above came from the coefficient of the \(y'\) term.

Even after all this work the right hand side integral is very tedious. It’s an example of the cyclic type so try using integration by parts twice and noticing that you end up where you started.

question: 4 (b)
sols_html:
We proceed as in the hint. Multiplying both sides by \(e^{2x}\) gives

\(\displaystyle e^{2x}y'' +2 e^{2x}y' = e^{2x}\cos x\)

Now, the left hand side is just \((e^{2x}y')'\) and so

\(\displaystyle (e^{2x}y')' = e^{2x}\cos x\)

Integrating both side, we see that the integral of the right hand side above is difficult - so we compute it separately. We proceed by integration by parts. Let

\[\begin{aligned} u = e^{2x} \quad & \quad v = \sin x \\ du = 2e^{2x}dx \quad & \quad dv = \cos x dx \end{aligned}\]

and so the integral becomes

\[\begin{aligned} \int e^{2x}\cos x \,dx &= e^{2x}\sin x - 2\int e^{2x}\sin x \, dx\end{aligned}\]

We use parts again. Let

\[\begin{aligned} u = e^{2x} \quad & \quad v = -\cos x \\ du = 2e^{2x}dx \quad & \quad dv = \sin x dx \end{aligned}\]

Then, we have

\[\begin{aligned} \int e^{2x}\cos x \,dx &= e^{2x}\sin x - 2\int e^{2x}\sin x \, dx\\ &= e^{2x}\sin x - 2\left( -e^{2x}\cos x + 2\int e^{2x}\cos x \, dx \right)\\ &= e^{2x}\sin x + 2 e^{2x}\cos x - 4\int e^{2x}\cos x \, dx\end{aligned}\]

This last integral on the right is the same as the integral on the left (up to a constant). Hence, we have

\[\begin{aligned} \int e^{2x}\cos x \, dx + 4\int e^{2x}\cos x \, dx &= e^{2x}\sin x + 2 e^{2x}\cos x +C \\ 5\int e^{2x}\cos x \, dx &= e^{2x}\sin x + 2 e^{2x}\cos x +C \\ \int e^{2x} \cos x \, dx &= \frac{e^{2x}\sin x }{5} + \frac{2e^{2x}\cos x}{5} +D \end{aligned}\]

where \(D = \frac{C}{5}\).

After this gigantic diversion, we return to the point. We had

\(\displaystyle (e^{2x}y')' = e^{2x}\cos x\)

and integrating both sides, we get

\(\displaystyle e^{2x}y' = \int e^{2x}\cos x \, dx = \frac{e^{2x}\sin x }{5} + \frac{2e^{2x}\cos x}{5} +D\)

Dividing both sides by \(e^{2x}\), we have

\(\displaystyle y' = \frac{\sin x }{5} + \frac{2\cos x}{5} + De^{-2x}\)

Now, we solve for \(D\). We plug in the initial condition \(y'(0) = -1\) and see that

\(\displaystyle -1 = y'(0) = \frac{\sin (0) }{5} + \frac{2\cos (0)}{5} + De^{-2(0)} = \frac{2}{5} + D\)

and so isolating, we see that \(D = -\frac{7}{5}\). Again integrating both sides of \(y'\) gives

\[\begin{aligned} y &= \int \frac{\sin x }{5} + \frac{2\cos x}{5} -\frac{7}{5}e^{-2x} \, dx \\ &= \frac{-\cos x }{5} + \frac{2 \sin x }{5} + \frac{7e^{-2x}}{10} + E\end{aligned}\]

where E is another constant. To compute E, we use the other initial condition that \(y(0) = 1\) to see that

\[\begin{aligned} 1 = y(0) &= \frac{-\cos (0) }{5} + \frac{2 \sin (0) }{5} + \frac{7e^{-2(0)}}{10} + E = -\frac{1}{5} + \frac{7}{10} + E\end{aligned}\]

and so \(E = \frac{1}{2}\). Combining gives

\[\begin{aligned} y &= \frac{-\cos x }{5} + \frac{2 \sin x }{5} + \frac{7e^{-2x}}{10} + \frac{1}{2}\end{aligned}\]

and we are finished!

&= e^{2x}\sin x + 2 e^{2x}\cos x  - 4\int e^{2x}\cos x \, dx
\end{align*}

This last integral on the right is the same as the integral on the left
(up to a constant). Hence, we have

\begin{align*}
\int  e^{2x}\cos x \, dx +  4\int e^{2x}\cos x  \, dx  &= e^{2x}\sin x + 2 e^{2x}\cos x +C \\
5\int e^{2x}\cos x \, dx  &= e^{2x}\sin x + 2 e^{2x}\cos x +C \\
\int e^{2x} \cos x \, dx  &= \frac{e^{2x}\sin x }{5} + \frac{2e^{2x}\cos x}{5} +D 
\end{align*}

where $D = \frac{C}{5}$.

After this gigantic diversion, we return to the point. We had

$\displaystyle (e^{2x}y')' = e^{2x}\cos x$

and integrating both sides, we get

$\displaystyle e^{2x}y' = \int e^{2x}\cos x \, dx = \frac{e^{2x}\sin x }{5} + \frac{2e^{2x}\cos x}{5} +D$

Dividing both sides by $e^{2x}$, we have

$\displaystyle y' =  \frac{\sin x }{5} + \frac{2\cos x}{5} + De^{-2x}$

Now, we solve for $D$. We plug in the initial condition $y'(0) = -1$ and
see that

$\displaystyle -1 = y'(0) = \frac{\sin (0) }{5} + \frac{2\cos (0)}{5} + De^{-2(0)} = \frac{2}{5} + D$

and so isolating, we see that $D = -\frac{7}{5}$. Again integrating both
sides of $y'$ gives

\begin{align*}
y &= \int  \frac{\sin x }{5} + \frac{2\cos x}{5} -\frac{7}{5}e^{-2x} \, dx \\
&= \frac{-\cos x }{5} + \frac{2 \sin x }{5} + \frac{7e^{-2x}}{10} + E
\end{align*}

where \emph{E} is another constant. To compute \emph{E}, we use the

\begin{align*}
1 = y(0) &= \frac{-\cos (0) }{5} + \frac{2 \sin (0) }{5} + \frac{7e^{-2(0)}}{10} + E = -\frac{1}{5} + \frac{7}{10} + E
\end{align*}

and so $E = \frac{1}{2}$. Combining gives

\begin{align*}
y &= \frac{-\cos x }{5} + \frac{2 \sin x }{5} + \frac{7e^{-2x}}{10} + \frac{1}{2}
\end{align*}

and we are finished!
